"Process controlling messages" option: Process control messages are displayed in Runtime if synchronization problems occur. For the process control messages 1012002-1012005, 1012018 and 1012021 you can set how often the process control messages are to be displayed in Runtime in the "Process control messages" field. Activate the "Send once" check box to have the process control messages shown only once. If you want to send the process control message several times in Runtime, deactivate the "Send once" check box. Enter the desired value in the "Send every ... minutes" input field or use the dial control.

Q: How can you control the frequency of process control messages display in Runtime according to the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Activate the 'Send once' check box to show messages only once, or deactivate it and set a frequency in the 'Send every ... minutes' field.
A2: To control the display frequency, either check 'Send once' for a single display or uncheck it and specify a time interval in minutes.
A3: The 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)' suggests using the 'Send once' option for one-time display or setting a recurring interval in minutes.
A4: For controlling message frequency, the manual recommends selecting 'Send once' or entering a time interval for repeated messages.
A5: Adjust the display frequency by toggling the 'Send once' checkbox or by defining a specific time interval for message recurrence.

Q: What is the purpose of the 'Time Synchronization' editor in OS server projects as mentioned in the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: It ensures OS clients receive their time from an OS server on the terminal bus.
A2: The 'Time Synchronization' editor is used to synchronize the time between OS clients and an OS server.
A3: According to the manual, its purpose is to manage time settings so clients can get accurate time from the server.
A4: It's designed for configuring time settings, allowing clients to synchronize their time with a server.
A5: The editor facilitates time synchronization across the network, ensuring all clients have consistent time settings.

Q: What is the role of the OS server in time synchronization as per the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: It provides the time reference for OS clients on the terminal bus.
A2: The OS server acts as the time source for clients within the terminal bus network.
A3: According to the manual, the server supplies the time that clients synchronize to.
A4: Its role is to ensure all connected clients maintain synchronized time settings.
A5: The server is central to time synchronization, offering a consistent time reference for clients.
